importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Hamas-led attack on southern Israel, which triggered the subsequent political and security crises and led to widespread criticism and calls for accountability.

The date of the announcement of Hanegbi's firing and the appointment of Gil Reich as acting national security adviser, marking a significant shift in Israel's security leadership amid ongoing tensions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline spans from the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack to the 2025 political realignment in Israel, highlighting the evolving security and political dynamics following the attack.

keyTakeAways: Tzachi Hanegbi, Israel's national security adviser, was fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, ending his three-year tenure as head of the National Security Council.
Gil Reich, deputy head of the NSC, has been appointed as acting head of the National Security Council following Hanegbi’s dismissal.

Hanegbi's departure is widely seen as a result of growing tensions with Netanyahu over disagreements on military strategy, particularly Hanegbi’s opposition to a full military takeover of Gaza City and his support for a partial deal with Hamas.

Hanegbi publicly admitted shared responsibility for the failures leading to the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack and called for a thorough investigation, which Netanyahu’s government has yet to establish.
The opposition, including former army chief Gadi Eisenkot, criticized the firing as an evasion of responsibility and a move to replace critical voices with loyalists.
Hanegbi, a veteran Likud politician and Netanyahu ally, held multiple ministerial roles in public security, intelligence, and regional cooperation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has fired Tzachi Hanegbi, the national security adviser, citing growing internal disagreements over military strategy, particularly Hanegbi’s opposition to a full military takeover of Gaza City and his advocacy for a partial deal with Hamas. Hanegbi, who served for three years, publicly acknowledged shared responsibility for the failures leading to the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack and called for a thorough investigation, which the government has yet to establish. In his place, Gil Reich, the deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head. The move has drawn criticism from the opposition, including former army chief Gadi Eisenkot, who accused Netanyahu and his cabinet of evading responsibility and replacing critical voices with loyalists, underscoring broader political and security tensions in Israel.
title: Israel’s Netanyahu fires national security chief amid Gaza tensions
